body:
Hi Albert,

I definitely recommend getting comfortable with Rhino and it will pay off a lot in the long run (Rhino's geometric capabilities are a lot greater than Sketchup in a number of key areas). It is also worth mentioning that, if you haven't used them yet, we have a few components that can help you manage and format your geometry in the way that E+ likes (including components to split building masses into core/perimeter zones and a component to ensure that there are reciprocal matching surfaces of adjacent zones).  These 3 videos in the Honeybee Energy Modeling tutorial series should help you use them in your workflow:

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cDvBWDA0aF0&list=PLruLh1AdY-SgW...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cDvBWDA0aF0&list=PLruLh1AdY-SgW4uDtNSMLeiUmA8YXEHT_&index=10)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DClON71RuuA&list=PLruLh1AdY-SgW...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DClON71RuuA&list=PLruLh1AdY-SgW4uDtNSMLeiUmA8YXEHT_&index=11)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nMQ2Pau4q6c&list=PLruLh1AdY-SgW...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nMQ2Pau4q6c&list=PLruLh1AdY-SgW4uDtNSMLeiUmA8YXEHT_&index=12)

-Chris
